nodes.text: Teachers' test-score value-added (VA) measures are informative about teacher quality and predict meaningful long-term student outcomes in adulthood
Value-added measures that control for lagged test scores exhibit little or no bias and can be treated as forecast-unbiased predictors of true teacher VA (from companion paper)

We link administrative school district records (grades 3-8, 1989-2009) to US federal tax records (1996-2011), matching about 90 percent of students to construct a longitudinal dataset of roughly one million individuals
Two empirical designs used: cross-classroom regressions controlling for rich observables and a quasi-experimental teacher turnover design comparing adjacent cohorts within school-grade cells
Cross-class estimates: a one standard deviation increase in teacher VA in a single grade raises college attendance at age 20 by 0.82 percentage points (mean 37 percent)
Cross-class estimates: a one standard deviation increase in teacher VA raises college quality (earnings-based index) by about $299 at age 20

Cross-class estimates: a one standard deviation increase in teacher VA in a single grade raises annual earnings at age 28 by about 1.3â€“1.65 percent (~$350), implying an approximate undiscounted lifetime income gain per student of $39,000 and a present value (discounted to age 12) of ~$7,000

Cross-class estimates: a one standard deviation increase in teacher VA reduces probability of teenage birth by 0.61 percentage points, raises neighborhood college graduate share by 0.25 percentage points, and raises 401(k) participation at age 28 by 0.55 percentage points

Quasi-experimental (teacher turnover) results: a one standard deviation improvement in mean teacher VA across cohorts raises college attendance at age 20 by 0.86 percentage points and raises college quality by about $198; estimates align closely with cross-class results

Estimation details that underpin identification: leave-year-out VA estimation to avoid correlated estimation error, control vectors include prior scores and rich student/class/parent covariates, standard errors clustered by school-cohort, and top-1% VA outliers trimmed for suspected test irregularities

Teacher VA impacts on test scores fade out rapidly over subsequent grades but reemerge in adulthood; tracking to future higher-VA teachers is small so reduced-form effects mainly reflect direct teacher impacts

Policy simulations: replacing a teacher in the bottom 5 percent of the VA distribution with an average teacher yields large gains in students' present value lifetime income (estimated ~$250,000 per classroom over a career accounting for drift; deselection using three years of VA data yields ~$185,000 per classroom); paying retention bonuses to high-VA teachers is less cost effective

Limitation and caveat: VA-based evaluation can induce behavioral responses such as teaching to the test or cheating that may erode VA signal quality; robustness requires monitoring and complementary measures

Conclusion: Test-score VA measures used appropriately are informative proxies for teachers' long-term impacts and could be a useful tool for personnel policy, but their use requires safeguards against manipulation and comparison to alternative measures (e.g., observations, principal evaluations)
